div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Alton S. Pope, July 28, 1927
div1.opener:
“Dunlora.” Box 453,
Charlottesville, Virginia.
July 28, 1927.
Dr. Alton S. Pope,
1308 East 56th. Street,
Chicago, Illinois.
Dear Doctor Pope:
div1.p:
Your letter of July 21st. has just reached me, after several
forwardings. I am so sorry for the delay!

Lest I keep you waiting longer, I am enclosing my only copy of
some Notes, prepared last [unclear]fall by Dr. Wade H. Frost (P.H.S. & J.H. S.J.H. request of
the Rockefeller Foundation, which will, I am sure, give you much of the
information you desire. I shall be very grateful for their return after
you have read them, as, although I am up here on sick leave, I get many
requests for biographic data about Father and these Notes of Dr. Frost's
contain the best detailed presentation of Father's work that has been written.

I much regrett that I have no reprints of the three articles on
the periods of incubation of yellow fever (Page 13, Frost's Notes), written
by Father prior to the findings of the Reed Board, but judge that you will
have no difficulty in fining them in the files of the Medical Journals to
which reference is given.

With very best remembrances to Dr. Geiger assuring you of the
pleasure it will always be to give you any additional data, which it is in
my power to supply,
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter
P. S. If you lecture from full notes, rather than headings, I need not
tell you how grateful and gratified I would be to have a copy of those you
make on Father's work.
P. S. Mem
Leake
(1) A note on the interval between infecting and secondary cases of yellow fever,
from the records of th yellow fever at Orwood, and Taylor, Miss. in 1898.”
New Orleans Med. & Surg. Jour., May 1900 (Also reprinted in the Annual Report
of the Marine Hospital Service for th year 1900.)
(2) A note on the spread of yellow fever in houses--extrinsic incubation.” Annual
Report of the Marine Hospital Service for the year 1900. (Also reprinted in Phila. Med.
Jour. June 15, 1901).
(3) The period of incubation of yellow fever. A study from unpublished obser-
vations. Med. Record. March 9, 1901.
Carter's study of incubation periods in y. f. began in 1888, as an inquiry es-
sential to the establishment of sound quarantine practice. Completed ten years later,
when epidemic at Orwood, Miss. furnished sufficient number of observations to satisfy
all his requirements.
The records were completed in October, 1898, but immediately thereafter, being or-
dered to Cuba to organize the quarantine service of the island, Carter found no oppor-
tunity to assemble his data and prepare them for publication until the winter of 1899-1900.
The three papers were prepared as a trilogy, the only one of the series actually
published before Reed's experiments were undertaken and reported being # (1).
